author: terence0083
content:
When requesting blobs by range. How are clients interpret `count`? Are we using it as a slot parameter or the number of commitment parameters? 
The spec currently has it as a slot parameter, and I wonder if we need further clarification

author: henridf
content: I've used it as slots, thought it seemed pretty natural that way

author: g11tech
content: number of commitments (blob side cars) , since those are the items piped back, also count limit is max deneb blocks * max blobs per block

author: g11tech
content: seems like clarification will be a good thing to have

author: terence0083
content:
Prysm is using it as slots. Looks like we have a split ðŸ˜„ 
So number of commitments is preferred here? I can open PR a a little bit to clarify

author: realbigsean
content: Wait yeah, thinking about this, when requesting you won't know how many blobs are in each slot, right? so should you just assume the max then at every block? it is actually odd

author: __kasey__
content: this is the reason slots seems more natural to me. also aligns with blocks by range.

author: g11tech
content: thats correct, so i guess both limits are essentially the same?

author: g11tech
content: but count should map to sidecars in my opinion

author: g11tech
content: as its more predictive (a client can specify lower limit of blobs)

author: __kasey__
content:
re limit, currently defined as 
`The response MUST contain no more than count * MAX_BLOBS_PER_BLOCK blob sidecars.`

author: __kasey__
content: which seems consistent

author: g11tech
content: hmmm ... then it def implies slots

author: realbigsean
content:
> Requests blob sidecars in the slot range [start_slot, start_slot + count), leading up to the current head block as selected by fork choice.
This is in the spec, and implies count is slots

author: __kasey__
content: yeah it's blobs /with reference to slots/

author: g11tech
content: although it would be more preditable for a client to specify side cars in terms of size (and bandwidth), but its fine with current specfication as well

author: g11tech
content: since slot boundaries need to be respected anyway

author: __kasey__
content: IMO clients control bandwidth by how quickly the read chunks

author: g11tech
content: not sure if there are any tests of long lived req/resp  connections/transfers (more than couple of seconds)

author: g11tech
content: although ping-pong  does keeps on going i think, so no reason not to suspect any issues

author: __kasey__
content: BeaconBlocksByRange v2 specifies `No more than MAX_REQUEST_BLOCKS_DENEB may be requested at a time.` but there is nothing like this for `BlobSidecarsByRange`. it is sort of implied that count should not be more than `MAX_REQUEST_BLOCKS_DENEB` maybe that could be made explicit.

author: henridf
content: Requesting by slot also makes it more straightforward to sync blocks and blobs in parallel, since by blob you don't know how many slots' worth you will get

author: __kasey__
content: considering part of the cost of responding is determining the canonical chain of blocks for blobs.
